channel.title: Comments on: Stupid me #2 – Where is my SSIS package executed?
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Koen Verbeeck
item.dc:creator: Koen Verbeeck
item.description: Such functionality would be nice indeed. No-one is stopping you from logging it into Connect :)
item.content:encoded: Such functionality would be nice indeed. No-one is stopping you from logging it into Connect ðŸ™‚

item.title: By: Valentino Vranken
item.dc:creator: Valentino Vranken
item.content:encoded:
Clutter could indeed become an issue. Unless you call it “Koen’s Test Job” and rename your package to something like “KoenTestJob.dtsx” while deploying ðŸ™‚

This makes me think of something I wish they’d had implemented: the ability to group jobs together (just for UI purposes). That would really help to avoid clutter in the Job Activity Monitor and we’d be able to put jobs of the same project in their own folder…

item.title: By: Koen Verbeeck
item.dc:creator: Koen Verbeeck
item.description: Creating a job on an UAT server just for executing a package once does seem like a lot of work :) (And it clutters the server.)
item.content:encoded: Creating a job on an UAT server just for executing a package once does seem like a lot of work ðŸ™‚ (And it clutters the server.)

item.title: By: Valentino Vranken
item.dc:creator: Valentino Vranken
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for the mention! ðŸ™‚

There’s actually a better “solution” than logging on to the remote server. Just create a job on that server to run the package. Then you can use SSMS on your client PC to start the job and thus you’re running the package on the remote server.
